themes.label: Decrees
themes.rationale: The text is explicitly identified as a dogma (decree) of the Amphictyonic Council.
themes.quote: δ γμ[α τ ν μφικτι ν]ων

themes.label: Honorific Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The inscription honors Callistus of Cnidus for his virtuous conduct and services to the Greeks, granting him proxeny and a golden crown.
themes.quote: παιν σαι τε κ λλιστον πιγ νους κν διον φ [ ι] χων ε νο διατελε πρ ς τε τ ς λλην δας π λεις

themes.label: Agonistic / Victory Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The decree grants the honoree the right of proedria (front seating) at the Pythian games and public proclamation at the gymnastic contests.
themes.quote: προεδρ αν ν πυθ οις κα ναγορε εσθαι α [τ ν ν τ ι γυ]μνικ ι γ νι

themes.label: Lists of Officials or Citizens
themes.rationale: The text concludes with a list of the ambassadors appointed to communicate the honors to the recipient.
themes.quote: πρεσβευτα ε ρ θησαν ντιγ νης κα γησ λαος [ο ---]ολ ου πρωτο[γ]νης πρωτ ρχου καλλε δας ε ξιθ ου δι δωρος δωροθ ου

themes.label: Stele
themes.rationale: The inscription is a monumental decree typically inscribed on a stone stele or block for public display in a sanctuary, though it also mentions a bronze statue.
themes.quote: στ σαι δ α το κα ε κ να χαλκ ν ν δελφο ς

themes.label: Marble
themes.rationale: Delphic decrees of this importance were commonly inscribed on high-quality stone such as marble, though the material is not explicitly named in the text.
themes.quote: δ γμ[α τ ν μφικτι ν]ων
themes.ambiguity_note: Material is inferred from archaeological context rather than the text itself.

rationale: This is a decree of the Amphictyonic Council from Delphi, dating to approximately 48 BC. It honors Callistus, son of Epigonus, a citizen of Cnidus, for his virtuous conduct and assistance to Greek cities while serving alongside Roman officials (the Emperor and legates). The honors include the title of proxenos and benefactor, a golden crown, a bronze statue in the sanctuary of Apollo, and special privileges at the Pythian games. The text concludes with the names of the ambassadors chosen to deliver the decree.
